div1.p: New-Antwerp, November 8, 1907. ANNEX TO THE LETTER FROM THE GOVERNOR Mr. Governor General,
I have the honor to confirm my telegram to you from this day as follows:

"Response to no. 739/f, from October 14. No 12/f, Consul "General of the United States to be moved to New-Antwerp September "II to Stanleyville nothing specific "to inform of for passage to New-Antwerp. Arrive in the after- "noon leave the next morning I learned after the Consul "General of the United States to be left at Upoto and around de- "tails by confidential letter."

As follows by this telegram, I have the honnor, Mr. Governor General, to communicate to you the following: Mr. Consul General of the United States, Smith, arrived at New- Antwerp by steamboat "Harry Read" around 2 1/2 hours from the afternoon, September 11. He quit the next morning by the first hour. The afternoon of the passage by Mr. Consul General had been consecrated by a walk in the cultures (Funtumia et Hevea) and at a visit to the lazaretto just as in the station. I have personally diven Mr. Consul General during this visit and the night of the dinner that I offered him, he announced strongly enchanted with his visit and of what he had seen in New-Antwerp.
Mr. Consul General Smith, while leaving New-Antwerp, told me that he had the intention of going as far as Stanleyville.
It was not so, for in fact, he stopped in Upoto. Something that I didn't know after his visit here, on the way down in October.

Following/After the details that were given to me by Mr. Substitute Detry, by his return to New-Antwerp, las November 2, Mr. Consul General Smith would have arrived in Upoto and from there in Lisala where he would have been invited to dine September 18. Assisted to dinner. Mr. Prosecutor of State Gréban de Saint Germain, Mr. Hutereau, Commander of
The next day, Mr. Consul General Smith left for Gali, accompanied by Reverand Dodds. For this trip I did not obtain any details.

From Gali, they went to Bayenge where they remained several days (from the 22nd-28th). The 27th, Mr. Substitue Detry arrived and Mr. Consul General Smith announced his departure for the next morning. During his stay in Bayenge, Mr. Consul General Smith wanted to proceed to experience the rubber harvest.

Driven by Mr. Everaert, they were taken to the forest accompanied by a certain nomber of workers. They proceeded to the harvest and after the information that supplied me by Mr. Detry, the result est that a man can produce, complete transfer, 3 kilos of rubber for two hours or work.

The 27th, in the evening, the dinner was presided by Mr. Substitute Detry. In the course of the conversation, Mr. Consul General Smith had volunteered this opinion: "I now realize the difficulties that they have here and from work that was made".

The 28th, in the morning, Mr. Smith, always accompanied by Mr. Dodds, left for Yambata where he arrived the same day. During the stay in Yambata, Mr. Speck, the Chief of the area, accompanied them the entire time. I know nothing specific to highlight.
From Yambata, the travelers left for Dobo where they arrived October 4, dinned there with Mr. Prosecutor of State Gréban de Saint Germian and from there, left October 5 to move.
October 10th, Mr. Consul General of the United States passed in New-Antwerp around the middle of the morning. He continued immediately.
Such are, Mr. Governor General, the information that I could obtain up to this day.
The Commissionary of the district, (s) Gehot.
